title: 108_hr5084
content: The Act may be cited as the "Smart from the Start Preschool Education for America Act of 2004" and provides formula grants to states for preschool education. The "Smart from the Start Preschool Education for America Act of 2004" aims to provide grants to states for high-quality, voluntary preschool education. The Secretary of Education will make grants to states that meet program quality standards for providing families access to preschool education. The Act requires the Secretary to develop program quality standards based on expert recommendations. Grant applications must include funding agreements, provide assurances of compliance, and contain necessary information. The Secretary determines the amount of grants reserved for territories and possessions. The Secretary reserves a portion of funds for territories, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations under the Act. Additionally, a specific percentage is allocated for state allotments after these reservations are made. The Secretary reserves funds for territories, tribes, and tribal organizations under the Act. States are allotted funds based on factors like young child and school lunch percentages. The young child factor is the ratio of children under 5 in the State to all States, while the school lunch factor is the ratio of children receiving free or reduced price lunches in the State to all States. The allotment percentage for a State is determined by dividing the per capita income of all individuals in the United States by the per capita income of all individuals in the State. If the allotment percentage exceeds 1.2 percent, it will be considered as 1.2 percent; if it is less than 0.8 percent, it will be adjusted to 0.8 percent. The per capita income for the State is determined by dividing the per capita income of all individuals in the United States by the per capita income of all individuals in the State. If the allotment percentage is less than 0.8 percent, it will be adjusted to 0.8 percent. Per capita income is calculated at 2-year intervals and is the average of the annual per capita incomes for the most recent 3 consecutive years. The curr_chunk defines "Indian tribe" and "outlying area" in the Act, referencing specific sections and territories. The curr_chunk defines terms related to education assistance under the Compact of Free Association, including the Secretary of Education and the definition of "State" and "tribal organization." The curr_chunk authorizes $5 billion for fiscal years 2005-2009 to carry out the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 for serving youth who are Indians or Native Hawaiians.
